It is now broadly accepted (following Edward Catich) that Roman letters were first written with a brush on the stone before being carved into stone. The same thing happened with Chinese characters, which were carved in stone just like they were written with a brush. The more pronounced rationalization of the Roman letterforms came much later starting in the Age of Enlightenment typefaces such as the Romain du Roi. Something similar happened to Chinese characters in printing, with the forms becoming more and more regular with straight lines until they looked very different from the forms written with a brush. So the explanation in the video is just wrong here. Better examples would have been Runic alphabets using only vertical and diagonal strokes or many Indic scripts such as Tamil and Balinese which favoured curved strokes so as not to damage the palm leaves they were written on.

I was surprised the Nāgarī script was called a syllabary. It is a prototypical example of an abugida, a category that has features of both an alphabet and a syllabary and is contrasted with both by specialists. It is ultimately derived from an abjad (probably Aramaic) with vowel signs added on, so it is very different in origin from true syllabaries like the Japanese kanas.

Inuktitut syllabics are also an abugida, though at least there is the excuse that the name makes it sound like a syllabary. But I have never seen the Indic scripts referred to as syllabaries. Abugidas are also called alphasyllabaries, so maybe that's where the confusion came from. Given the prominence of abugidas in several regions of the world (including Southeast Asia and the Horn of Africa), it would have been nice to treat them separately.

Also, while talking about the Nāgarī syllabary (sic), the examples shown were of Devanagari script, one of the modern descendants of Nāgarī script. Why not just call it the Devanagari script, since that is the name most used in English? Why use a name that strictly refers to one of the early stages of the script, even if it is sometimes used interchangeably with Devanagari? If you wanted to cover all such writing systems in the region you could have referred to the Brahmic scripts or Indic scripts.

The writing systems in India, that use Devanagari and Inuktitut are typically referred to as _Abugidas_, rather than syllabaries, exactly because vowel sound information is both mandatory and written, but as a diacritic or modification, rather than a stand-alone letter.
This differs from abjads -- like Arabic -- where vowels are optional or missing, and differs from syllabaries where each unique syllable gets a unique symbol.

Ke Ka Ko Ki in a Syllabary (Japanese): け か こ き. Note how they're all completely different
Ke Ka Ko Ki in an Abugida (Hindi): के का को की. Note how they all contain क as their base symbol

(apologies if I got any of the symbols wrong, Google translate isn't entirely accurate)

Why can't there be a spelling reform? Just take the standard version of English of the specific country and change its spelling. Dialect speakers can figure out how to spell their dialects on their own. I'm German, and we had our last spelling reform in 2006. There are other countries that have German as one official language and they partly made other spelling reforms, like Switzerland that completely dropped the ß (it makes a ss-sound), unlike Germany German that just made a rule for when to use it, so you don't have to learn by heart when to put it, resulting in its use in partly other words than before. Speakers of other German dialects than the standard one are making rules to write their dialect, and there's even a Bavarian Wikipedia. So yeah, even if you just reform the spelling of standard English (of one country), it would already be great for learners. And who cares about small differences like runnin/running? We have something similar with verbs. E.g. fliegen (its means to fly). It's said as fliegn, so no one pronounces the second e, apart from cases like rennen (to run) where you have to use it to separate the nn and n. No one cares tbh.
The fact that even Shakespeare wasn't sure how to spell his name comforts me

I absolutely LOVE the Mayan writing system, so I'll explain some more abt it:
Like Japanese, it's a combo of a syllabary and a logography. Just looking at it is already so beautiful, but perhaps even cooler is how it works, and its flexibility. Graphemes are arranged into word blocks, and most syllabograms have many different ways to write them. What this means is that there are so many different ways to write the same thing, and they're all correct! It's almost like making artistic choices, which probably isn't too far from the truth, historically speaking. Ahtzib means both scribe and artist in (Classical?) Mayan. There are also varying degrees of "fanciness" or formality you can write with. Writing on stone (the most common surviving type iirc) is really a work of art, while more practical styles exist on pottery and somewhat in the 3 remaining codices. Tho bc of this, it's been a slow process to digitize the system and make it typable, but eventually (I'd guess certainly within our lifetimes) it should be possible!

Idk where to better fit this and don't like to end on a bad note, but it's important to acknowledge that conquistadors burning literally entire libraries of Maya writing, to the point that only 3 Mayan codices survive. Even tho the Mayan civ(s) were already in decline by the time Europeans arrived, they are also the reason why Maya writing had to be deciphered in the first place. Among other awful language policies, made sure that Maya scribes/scholars couldn't pass on how to write to following generations (tho in old Maya society only a small sliver of the population was literate, as often was the case in old literate societies, but ofc this doesn't mean it's justified). The Spanish justified it by calling the language and its writing demonic

There are three terms in the conlang community for the two most non-transparent kinds of orthographies (writing systems). It's late at night for me, so I can't drag them out of the depths of my mind , so I'll describe them in descriptive terms. If you wan see something on the page and more or less figure it out with some nudging (Dutch, Italian, Spanish, Basque, Finnish), those writing systems are considered shallow. On the opposite end, you have Tibetan, which requires a lot of rote knowledge to decipher in spite of being written with a script adjacent to an alphabet.

Now, here's the bit that will annoy English speakers.

English spelling is a hot mess. If you know how English was spoken almost a millenium ago, it's much easier, but it's still hard, because it's hard to go from how something is written down to show it ought to be pronounced.

Meanwhile, you have languages with complex spelling systems that are actuallly somewhat straightforward. Why? Because if you can read them (in spite of their complexities) you can pronounce them. So, the likes of French and Irish, in spite of how alien they may appear at first glance, and actually much simpler than people would otherwise expecxt.

To add to this, Irish has a massive shift two millenia ago, which gave use the shift between "primitive" (or in Latin/Greek terms "classical") Irish and Old Irish. Being an isolated archipelago, things were slightly more complicated, but it left us all with something very alien from SA-I-E. Where the influence came from is another matter, and that's complicated.

I get the feeling that this episode was extremely rushed. A lot of what was covered here is very oversimplified. :( Spelling can also vary across a language in the same way pronunciation does. Even the example in the video - running/runnin - shows that. And I wish this episode covered ideographic symbols in language, in depth, especially because emojis are a part of language, and one that is cross-culture. But a really important point: Whoa, you skipped right over Proto-Sinaitic. Phoenician wasn't where the letter B started. I get kind of miffed when people only go as far back as Phoenician. It also is dangerous to say that linguists are more focused on how people say something that being focused on what they're saying, because linguistics absolutely includes focus on understanding meaning. :/ In fact, I would say it is more important and more like a linguist to focus on meaning and nuances of language than on superficial form. I mean, otherwise, you get middle-school English teachers saying "I don't know 'can' you got to the bathroom", because they don't know what deontic modality is, nor than "can" has it. :s

To answer the question about spelling reform.  The same way it has been done in the past.  Every time a nation need to make a standard spelling, when the switch from one script to another, they just went with a mix of the most common dialects.  It is not perfect, but nothing is and spelling reform does make it better.
